goals.name: G1
goals.short_description: The widespread adoption of the trustworthy assurance methodology could help establish a more responsible and trustworthy ecosystem of digital mental health technologies.

property_claims.name: P1
property_claims.short_description: Trustworthy assurance provides a structured method for responsible project governance through internal reflection and participatory engagement.

evidence.name: E1
evidence.short_description: The project lifecycle model scaffolds reflective and deliberative activities, providing a shared structure for project teams.

evidence.name: E2
evidence.short_description: Assurance case elements have a clear relational structure to help teams identify gaps in an argument e.g. claims with missing evidence that help teams identify necessary actions)

property_claims.name: P2
property_claims.short_description: Trustworthy assurance requires participatory processes that facilitate the diverse inclusion of diverse stakeholder perspectives.

evidence.name: E3
evidence.short_description: Stakeholder engagement can support the co-creation of generalisable patterns, as seen in this report.

evidence.name: E4
evidence.short_description: Stakeholder engagement can help anticipate potential risks and adverse impacts that a project team may not have otherwise identified.

property_claims.name: P3
property_claims.short_description: Trustworthy assurance facilitates accountability and transparent communication between developers and affected stakeholders.

evidence.name: E5
evidence.short_description: Building an assurance case is a process of documentation, and the result can be shared with stakeholders who can verify the accuracy and sufficiency of the case.

evidence.name: E6
evidence.short_description: Robust and well-validated standards can be used to help teams identify appropriate or permissible forms of evidence.
